nodes.text: Individual teacher quality has a substantial causal impact on elementary student achievement
Previous literature finds little consistent relation between observable teacher credentials and student achievement, motivating identification of teacher fixed effects

Method: Use panel data from two contiguous New Jersey elementary districts (1989-90 to 2000-01), with student and teacher identifiers, nationally standardized reading and math test scores (NCE scale), controls for student fixed effects, classroom variables, school-year effects, and teacher fixed effects with an experience function
Result: Teacher fixed effects are large and statistically significant predictors of student test scores across reading and math subjects
Claim: Teaching experience has positive effects on reading achievement controlling for teacher fixed effects, with most gains concentrated in early years and up to about ten years
Conclusion: Policies to improve student achievement should emphasize measured teacher performance rather than relying solely on credentials like degrees or certification
Evidence: A one standard deviation increase in teacher quality raises reading test scores by ~0.20 standard deviations (NCE scale)
Evidence: A one standard deviation increase in teacher quality raises math test scores by ~0.24 standard deviations (NCE scale)
Result: Ten years of teaching experience raises reading vocabulary and comprehension by about 4 NCE points (~0.2 SD); math subjects show little consistent positive experience gains

Evidence / Claim: Naive estimates that omit teacher fixed effects understate experience effects because teacher fixed effects and experience are correlated across teachers; controlling for fixed effects materially changes estimated experience returns
Result: Classroom-specific controls (class size, peers average past test score, split-level class indicators) are not significant predictors of test scores in these districts after controls

Result: Variance decomposition lower bound indicates teacher effects account for a nontrivial share of policy-relevant test score variance (estimated lower bounds ~4-9% and upper bounds ~16-23% under assumptions)
Limitation: Data cover only two similar New Jersey districts and elementary grades; generalization to other districts, grades, or national distribution may be limited

Assumption: Identification relies on panel observation of students and teachers across years, student fixed effects, school-year effects, and a cutoff assumption restricting experience effects beyond a defined tenure
